data.title: Issues with reliability and usability of  built in Extension command line commands, and Question about metrics and guidance.
data.body:
I have been working on a PowerShell Module for working with VSCode Extensions and Metrics. This project got started by looking for a better way to get metrics on Publishers and Extensions. I have a large number of published extension, roughly 300 or so which are mostly themes, and found it was almost impossible to really get any sort of idea on numbers.

My module can be found here [VSCodeExtensions](https://github.com/gerane/VSCodeExtensions)

When implementing my `Install-VSCodeExtension` and `Uninstall-VSCodeExtension` I first tried to use wrappers around the `code --install-extension` and `code --uninstall-extension`. I found it incredibly difficult to work with the built in commands. 
- The first issue I encountered, is the cmd returns before the JS does, so there is no way to capture the output to error handle. This also might potentially be the reason why PowerShell ISE gets zero output from --list-extensions. If you run the command to get installed extension in the ISE it does not show any output. I felt this issue was related enough for this issue, but if it is not I can open up a separate issue.
- When I first started to write Pester tests for my wrappers, I had to stop because the internal wrapped commands weren't reliable enough to test. If you look in that repo will notice, I really don't have any Pester unit/integration tests for that project, and that is because I don't want to write them only to have to change my whole implementation because the internal commands are not reliable. So right now, I have everything written in PowerShell. Gtting installed extensions and versions is just parsing the package.jsons, finding packages I am using the cache url, uninstalling packages I am removing all versions of extension folders, and to install I am getting the asseturi, downloading vsix, unpacking vsix, moving to vscode folder and then renaming manifest and moving to vscode folder. Then I added an update command to find latest installed versions and then check to see if theres an update and updates if available. I like this one for my powershell profile.
- Since the output comes from a separate process, I cannot catch the output in a variable for use in powershell. 

My solution was to replicate the installation in pure powershell. I can actually control the errors and what causes them. I much prefer this method as I am not dependent on an external cmd file. One thing I did not replicate was the added metadata that is added into the package.json, and I could easily do this for 99% of the data, but there was one field I was uncertain about. The "X-Market-User-Id" I was seeing odd and different results. I look at some, and the value was a long randon string, and then others would be "someValue.machineID". The other issue was the amount of metadata has been inconsistent. 

Sometimes you might get a large amount of metadata like this

``` json
{
"__metadata": {
        "galleryApiUrl": "https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/_apis/public/gallery",
        "id": "7a8e7281-d65b-4a07-b901-0cd5756fa98e",
        "publisherId": "a5c25faf-bf60-4941-81b9-9a852b96c5fb",
        "publisherDisplayName": "gerane",
        "installCount": 420,
        "versions": [
            {
                "version": "0.0.2",
                "date": "2016-04-27T21:22:48.88Z",
                "downloadHeaders": {
                    "X-Market-Client-Id": "VSCode",
                    "User-Agent": "VSCode",
                    "X-Market-User-Id": "95e28e718b572a5c28f0d6acfd3c5c00ad85a8df6de64cebe9fbd63ff73d69f3"
                },
                "downloadUrl": "https://gerane.gallery.vsassets.io/_apis/public/gallery/publisher/gerane/extension/Theme-TomorrowNight/0.0.2/assetbyname/Microsoft.VisualStudio.Services.VSIXPackage?install=true",
                "manifestUrl": "https://gerane.gallery.vsassets.io/_apis/public/gallery/publisher/gerane/extension/Theme-TomorrowNight/0.0.2/assetbyname/Microsoft.VisualStudio.Code.Manifest"
            },
            {
                "version": "0.0.1",
                "date": "2015-11-22T08:18:07.117Z",
                "downloadHeaders": {
                    "X-Market-Client-Id": "VSCode",
                    "User-Agent": "VSCode",
                    "X-Market-User-Id": "95e28e718b572a5c28f0d6acfd3c5c00ad85a8df6de64cebe9fbd63ff73d69f3"
                },
                "downloadUrl": "https://gerane.gallery.vsassets.io/_apis/public/gallery/publisher/gerane/extension/Theme-TomorrowNight/0.0.1/assetbyname/Microsoft.VisualStudio.Services.VSIXPackage?install=true",
                "manifestUrl": "https://gerane.gallery.vsassets.io/_apis/public/gallery/publisher/gerane/extension/Theme-TomorrowNight/0.0.1/assetbyname/Microsoft.VisualStudio.Code.Manifest"
            }
        ]
    }
}
```

Then other times you might just get 3 small pairs at the bottom.

``` json
    "__metadata": {
        "id": "14f7c4fd-fedf-4513-a31a-163a1b07a997",
        "publisherId": "a5c25faf-bf60-4941-81b9-9a852b96c5fb",
        "publisherDisplayName": "gerane"
    }
```

I am not sure what your recommended way of handling this would be. I know the metadata is not required, but I am not quite sure what that impacts. The other reason is the built in commands are about as basic as they can get. Writing this native in powershell lets me build in pipeline support and ability to query by any property. This allows me to do things like this

``` powershell
Find-VSCodeExtension -ExtensionName * -category Snippets -Tag *type* -PublisherName 'gerane' | Install-VSCodeExtension
```

How does VSCode handle the metrics for extension installs? I am guessing having this external to the built in command lines is going to break the install metrics, but it just was not reliable enough to use for me. It would be nice if Code offered a native powershell module for Windows, but since I am not so sure that will happen, I was hoping I could get a little guidance on the direction I should go. If anything, maybe I can get some support or potentially work with the PowerShell extension in some way.

One thing I am worried about, is the apis or uris that are currently accessible, might be removed one day without warning.

There is another issue with --uninstall-extension that I will open a second ticket for. It is only uninstalling the latest version. So if you have 6 versions installed, you have to run the command 6 times to actually remove the extension.

cc @daviwil 
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run large number of Install/uninstall extensions
2. Occasional unexplained failures with no way of knowing cause.

data.title: Auto closing brackets not functioning for c# in 1.3.0-insider
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.3.0-insider
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create new c# file (.cs)
2. Type the following `void Foo() {` and the bracket fails to auto close.

I have test both the c#, and legacy c# extensions and both fail to close the brackets in the in insiders edition. Both plugins work properly in 1.2.1.

The auto closing bracket also works properly in 1.3.0-insider for other tested languages C, C++, JS, PHP.

data.title: Cannot access extensions search result using the keyboard
data.body:
- VSCode Version: insiders 7/1
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Extensions
2. Press Tab key
   -> Extensions search results get focus, but I can not get to the individual extensions using the arrow keys or the tab key.

data.title: Screenreader issues in global search/replace
data.body:
VSCode Version: insiders 7/1
OS Version: Windows
1. Open Search Pane
2. Search for a string with matches in your workspace
3. Tab to the first search result
4. Tab to the Replace or Remove button on the right end of  a search match

-> screenreader remains silent when those buttons have focus

data.title: [html] tokenizer state holds attribute value and runs OOM
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install VS Code
2. Open Folder with 12 Mb html file.
3. "The window has crashed"

There isn't a noticeable increase in memory or CPU usage. Running as Admin or opening it as a single file makes no difference.

This seems similar to "Crashing/failing to open on new install #8400" except that it seems that I need to open a file first.

data.title: Debugging fails if Stopped event occurs before command Response.
data.body: There appears to be an issue with the VS Code Debug Protocol. When a step or continue command is issued it is possible to get a stopped event before the command response. This occurs occasionally in the C# and C++ debugger extension. When this occurs you can no longer debug with VS Code. It no longer appears in break mode, but you cannot get out without stopping debugging.

data.title: Allow extensions to handle launching of the debug adapter.
data.body:
It would be nice if extensions could be in the loop when launching the debug adapter sub-process:
- This would allow the extension to alter adapter's command line options depending on workspace configuration and/or pass the relevant bits of configuration to the adapter.
- In cases when adapter is implemented on top of system debugger, this would allow the extension to locate a proper binary (for example, `lldb` could be installed as `lldb.X.Y` on some systems).
- Extension could provide better error messages should the adapter exit abnormally.

- OS Version:Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Open vscode, change app size/position, exit
2. Re-open vscode - app should use last size/position
3. Open additional instance using CLI (vscode -n <some folder>) - app uses default window size/position

data.title: Add "breakpoint created/deleted" notifications.
data.body:
Some debuggers have much more flexible ways of setting breakpoints than VSCode currently supports (e.g. set breakpoints by regex).  Would be nice if breakpoints created via commands in debugger console were reflected in the UI.

I'd suggest adding a new notification message to the protocol, which adapter can send when a  breakpoint is created/deleted.  It should include a "cookie" that needs to be passed back to the adapter in order to re-create the breakpoint.

data.title: Debug popup collapses when mouse goes into the debug console
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. While debugging with the debug console displaying, hover over an object so that the popup will partially be displayed in the debug console.
2. Move the mouse into the debug popup and start moving it down until is crosses into the debug console.
3. The debug popup will collapse.  As long as the mouse is in the code window section of the popup, you are OK.  But as soon as you drift into the debug console (you're still within the debug popup), the popup will collapse.
4. See the attachment

![debugwindowbug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6989056/16532408/614cab2e-3f97-11e6-82d6-27482b881184.png)

data.title: Urls in markdown files do not get the "hyperlink" styles in preview and are not clickable as well
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a markdown file type in a url
2. Open preview
3. The url is neither clickable nor does it have the styles of a hyperlink

In older versions (mine is 1.2.1 dated 6/14), the url would appear as a hyperlink and on clicking a browser instance would open up using the url.

Note: Links added using the right markdown syntax as below work just fine
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16890566/16531337/d63636ce-3f80-11e6-9d41-f31b1b264bb9.png)

data.title: Remove .pp from Ruby extension list. Issue #5366
data.body:
The *.pp file extension as it pertains it Ruby is actually
a file type used to denote a Puppet Manifest written in the Puppet
DSL (which itself is written in Ruby). The affected setting was
overriding VSCode Puppet extensions that are expecting the .pp
extension to be detected as file type Puppet.

data.title: Regex Lookbehind doesn't work
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 Home Edition

Steps to Reproduce:
1. type "a b"
2. search text ( CTRL +F)
3. use regular expression (ALT+R)
4. type (?<=\w)\s(?=\w)
5. The Error Message Appears "Invalid Regular Expression: /(?<=\w)\s(?=\w)/: Invalid Group" and no results are found.
   It should instead match the space character between 'a' and 'b'.

data.title: Loads empty screen with the last line of a file at the beginning

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.5 (15F34)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. have a 2560*1440px screen
2. have a 57-line source code file
3. start VSCode with `code .` command from command-line
4. maximize VSCode window (not full screen mode)
5. click on that source file from the sidebar
6. get empty screen scrolled all the way down to line 57 with the rest of the coding area empty:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/159209/16528637/f3de64de-3f72-11e6-96ac-710b13c849ec.png)

scrolling up just shows the rest of the file, but why does it load the last line to the top of the screen? it is often an empty line...
